bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Albert E. Truby, April 10, 1941

div1.p: In evaluating the Reed versus Finlay debate, Kean states that Reed converted a discredited hypothesis into an established doctrine.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Albert E. Truby, April 10, 1941
div1.opener:
Brig. Gen. A. E. Truby
USA Ret.
2804 N STREET, N. W.
GEORGETOWN
WASHINGTON, D. C.
April 10, 1941
My dear Truby
div1.p:
Are you quite ready to give me
up as a hopeless correspondent?
If so I would not blame you in
the least. I have no one to beat
the type writer for me and have
had a great deal of writing to do
in the part three months. You
know what the demand of our
friend Hench can be when he is
hot on the trail and have had
several other irons in the fire.
The Thos. Jefferson memorial has
got to a point where I could do
something and I have been the
working member of the Committee on
2
inscription, and it is surprising
how far afield that has taken me.
For one item I have read all of
Abraham Lincoln's speeches in
his contest with Douglass in 1859
-60 and I wish I had read them
fifty years ago. I wanted to see
just what connection there was between
Jefferson's abolition activities has
with Lincolns. T. J. began to attack
the slave trade before the Revolution
and finally secured its prohibition
when he was President in 1808.
He was determined to limit the
spread of slavery to the Mississippi
Valley and in the old continental
Congress just missed having it pro-
hibited in Alabama Mississippi Tenna-
see & Kentucky by one vote. The law
which prohibited it in the Northwest
3.
Territory which Virginia gave to the
union to be made into five states was
drawn up by him but did not pass
until after he left the Congress to be
our minister to France, but Lincoln
gave him the credit for it. It was
the effort of Douglass to repeal this
law which brought on his contest
with Lincoln. The commission seem
averse to having any mention made
of this life-long warfare against
slavery on the part of Jefferson
but I cannot see why. Then Dr.
Francisco Dominguez has sent me his
book 300 pages of excellent French printed
in Paris to show that Dr. Carlos Finlay
was the whole cheese and that Walter
Reed only verified facts which Finlay
had already proved experimentally.
But he does not explain - none of them
do - why it was that neither he nor
C2
B5
4.
any of the doctors in Havana or elsewhere
accepted the discovery until Reed & his
assistants came along and demonstrated
it so that in the words of Goldberger
of the Public Health Service Reed “converted
a discredited hypothesis into an established
doctrine”. There is the crux of the matter
in 8 words. I am willing to agree that
Dr. Finlay discovered the rôle of the
mosquito and Major Reed demonstrated
it. They dont say anything about
the infected clothing experiment which
was of such far reaching importance
yet even Gorgas did not accept that
until August 1901 and in spite of
the Dept. Order to do so did not stop
the disinfection of bedding & clothing
until Aug 15 1901. I am very curi-
ous to hear from Dr. Hench how he is
getting along with them. Well I have
had quite a correspondence with Dr.
5.
Apr 10, 1941
2804 N STREET, N. W.
GEORGETOWN
WASHINGTON, D. C.
Dominquez & my old friend & neighbor
Dr. Angles in Quemados about
some of the current mis-statements
in Dr. D's, book. He has a very good
photograph of Schuler's bust of Reed
with the statement under it that the
inscription is
Walter Reed
1851 - 1902
Surgeon (Major) U. S. Army

“ President of the Board of Army Medical Officers that
discovered and demonstrated in 1901 the transmis-
sion of yellow fever by mosquitoes (Since 1921 at
the National Gallery of Art, Washington D.C.”
I think it was in 1934 that you moved this bust
out to Walter Reed Hospital where it properly
belongs - so I got Ireland to phone out there
and find out what was in fact the in-
scription under it. The answer was simply
his name Walter Reed and no more.
Then I phoned to the Army Medical Museum
where they have a replica of it in bronze
also by Schuler. The reply was there was no
inscription - not even his name.
There I phoned to the National Museum (not of Art.)
6
and after much research they found in
their files a photograph of the bust and
a copy of the inscription, for which the
Assistant Curator, Mr. Whitefread hastened
to say that the Historical Section was
responsible, which was about as Dr
Dominguez had stated. But I could
assume his that it had been removed
before his book was printed. Angle's
had written me that the inscription with the
objectionable word “discovered” in it was
in the National Capital. So much for
that. Well I finally rounded up
Ireland one morning when he had nothing
on his mind and we read the entire
correspondence that you sent me about
Carroll and Agramonte. He said he
didnt know any thing about it but what
you and I told him. I said that his func-
tion was not to give information but to
he the jury to hear the facts and give
a finding. So after he had considered
7.
the evidence he said that he did not
think it was of any great importance
to decide whether Agramonte really
did take care of the mosquitoes or only
thought he did, or whether he really was
present when Lazear put the mosquito
on Dean, which you and I very much
doubt. His feeling is, and I agree with him
that it is a pity to bring discredit after all
these years on these men that are dead
for differences of statement in details
that are of no great importance.
Let us help Dr. Hench all we can in his
efforts to get to the bottom of things but
not to do any much raking. And I
am inclined to let the Cubans have Dr
Finlay as the discoverer, as he was, altho
we may have our doubts about his
very wild cases of yellow fever caused
by unripe mosquitoes. Reed is secure
in his fame. He did what he set out
to do and all the world knows it. Now
C2
B5
8
when men who pose as historians like
Burton J. Hendrick, and he has written
some valuable books, try to robe Reed
of some of his glory to give it to Gorgas
who dont need it and who reaped
all the financial and other rewards
then I say lets put up a fight and
let the truth be known. Gorgas
never made any such claims and
we wont let any one else make them.

In the nice letter that you wrote
me at Christmas you ask if Mrs Ames
ever got her bill through. I dont
think she did. Love promised to
let me know if she or Lambert or
any of the other claimants got by &
he never has. Old Senator Sheppard
who was Chairman of the Senate Military
Committee was her long suit and got
a favorable report from his committee
but he died yesterday & I hope the
9
Apr 10, 1941
bill will die with him.

2804 N STREET, N. W.
GEORGETOWN
WASHINGTON, D. C.

I had a postal from Dr Hench from
Havana this apt. signed by him and
by Moran. I had written to him there
and, inter alia, I mentioned that I
had never received the photo copies
of the Hemmeter-Carroll Correspondence
that he said he had mailed me.
In this postal he explains that
he sent that to you and you
were to read it and send it to
me at your convenience. So now
I feel better and have just poured
out a drink, it being 5-30 max
Herbert Slocum used to say. First
drink time and will drink to your
health and that of the dear lady who
is your wife, and when I have second
I will drink success to little King Peter II
of Serbia who certainly needs all the good
C2
B5
10
wishes and airplanes that we can send
him. Cornelia Kean joins me in
good wishes to you both and I am

closer.seg:
P.S. This is a long letter and I am not
going to read it over. If I have written
the wrong letter or spelled any word
differently from the way my 10 volume
Century Dictionary does just re-
member that I will be 81 in June
and overlook it.
